com.sharneng.lookup.fluent

Interface Indexing<E,T>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of source data
    T - the element type of the lookup being built
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Indexed<E,T>, Selected<E,T>, Sourced<E,T>

    public interface Indexing<E,T>
    Represent a status of the fluent API that the indexing is allowed.
    Author:
    Kenneth Xu

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Defined<Lookup<?>> by(Converter<E,Object>... converters)
      Index the source data by multiple converters that can compute index value from the source data.
      Indexed<E,Lookup<T>> by(Converter<E,Object> converter)
      Index the source data by the converter that can compute index value from the source data.
      Defined<Lookup<?>> by(String... expressions)
      Index the source data by the properties and/or computed values specified by multiple expressions.
      Indexed<E,Lookup<T>> by(String expression)
      Index the source data by the property or computed value specified by the expression.

    • Method Detail

      • by

        Indexed<E,Lookup<T>> by(String expression)
        Index the source data by the property or computed value specified by the expression.
        Parameters:
        expression - the OGNL expression to index the source data
        Returns:
        an instance of Indexing that can be further indexed

      • by

        Defined<Lookup<?>> by(String... expressions)
        Index the source data by the properties and/or computed values specified by multiple expressions.

        Avoid this method unless you don't know now many levels of index you want to create. by("index1").by("index2").Defined.index() is a better alternative than by("index1", "index2").Defined.index() because former returns type Lookup<Lookup<Something>> v.s. the other returns just Lookup<?>.

        Parameters:
        expressions - the OGNL expressions to index the source data
        Returns:
        an instance of Defined that can be used to create the lookup

      • by

        Indexed<E,Lookup<T>> by(Converter<E,Object> converter)
        Index the source data by the converter that can compute index value from the source data.
        Parameters:
        converter - an instance of Converter that computes index value from source data
        Returns:
        an instance of Indexing that can be further indexed

      • by

        Defined<Lookup<?>> by(Converter<E,Object>... converters)
        Index the source data by multiple converters that can compute index value from the source data.

        Avoid this method unless you don't know now many levels of index you want to create. by(c2).by(c1).Defined.index() is a better alternative than by(c1, c2).Defined.index() because former returns type Lookup<Lookup<Something>> v.s. the other returns just Lookup<?>.

        Parameters:
        converters - multiple instances of Converter that compute multilevel index values from source data
        Returns:
        an instance of Defined that can be used to create the lookup
